I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Under  its  Strategy  2020,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  identified 
environmentally sustainable growth as a top development concern and has made environment, 
including climate change, a core area of operations.1 Consistent with the agreements under the 
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), including the Bali Action 
Plan, ADB’s climate change priorities for action,2 adopted in 2010, emphasize the use of finance, 
technology, and capacity building as tools to address climate change. Enabling the transfer and 
spread of technology is, therefore, central to the global effort to combat climate change and a 
means to help developing countries address both climate change and energy security.3 
 
2.  The  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  seek  to  pilot  a  center  that  will  help 
coordinate assistance in Asia and the Pacific to accelerate the development and deployment of 
climate change mitigation and adaptation technologies. The center will support the aims and 
activities of the Technology Mechanism established under the UNFCCC. The project will be 
undertaken jointly with the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) and other partners, 
with funding support expected from the Global Environment Facility (GEF).4 This TA will serve 
as the vehicle to implement the project components that are to be conducted by ADB. The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Global climate change poses increasingly important challenges for developing countries 
in the Asia and Pacific region. The region’s rapid economic growth and structural change have 
been closely associated with the worldwide rise in greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Emissions 
from its energy sector, for example, have grown by 194% since 1990. If this trend is allowed to 
continue, the region could account for 45% of global energy emissions by 2030 from 33% in 
2008.6 The region’s response to climate change could make or break global mitigation efforts. At 
the same time, Asia and the Pacific are particularly vulnerable to global warming’s adverse 
effects. The region is expected to face increasingly frequent and severe  extreme weather 
events,  including  floods,  droughts,  and  tropical  storms,  as  well  as  rising  sea  levels  and 
unpredictable changes in precipitation patterns. This may reduce the availability of freshwater, 
lead to falling crop and fisheries productivity, and increase the occurrence of diseases such as 
dengue fever and malaria. Large population centers, industrial areas, and key infrastructure that 
are located in vulnerable geographical areas may be put at risk. These impacts would seriously 
threaten the livelihoods of large populations, particularly vulnerable groups such as women and 
children, and undermine economic growth and poverty reduction efforts across the region. 
 
4.  A key tool for addressing both rising emissions and vulnerability to climate change is the 
effective development, transfer, and deployment of technologies. The 16th Conference of the 
Parties  to  the  UNFCCC  in  Cancun,  Mexico  in  December  2010  reached  an  agreement  to

establish a global Technology Mechanism to facilitate the implementation of actions to achieve 
technology  development  and  transfer  based  on  national  circumstances  and  priorities.  The 
Parties agreed to create a Technology Executive Committee and a Climate Technology Center 
and  Network  under  this  mechanism.  Many  of  the  Parties  saw  regional  organizations  as 
important conduits between the global center and a network of participants scattered across 
countries and regions. The Parties also emphasized the importance of creating a strong linkage 
between the UNFCCC's Technology and Financial Mechanisms. As a regional development 
bank in Asia and the Pacific, ADB has much to contribute to this global effort. 
 
5.  The  opportunity  to  generate  benefits  from  new  technological  tools  is  especially 
significant in developing countries where rapid expansion of relatively long-lived capital stocks 
using incumbent technologies threatens to lock in GHG emission patterns for decades to come. 
New technology is also needed to adapt to the adverse impacts that are bound to occur due to 
existing  levels  of  GHG  concentration  in  the  atmosphere.  These  tools  include  better  water 
treatment  and  supply  technology,  improved  crop  varieties,  and  better  technologies  for 
agricultural water management and flood protection. Public financial resources alone will not 
meet the large-scale overall investment needs of low-carbon, climate-resilient development. 
These  requirements  are  expected  to  reach  $140  billion–$175  billion  a  year  by  2030  for 
mitigation  in  the  world’s  developing  countries,7 and  $40  billion  annually  for  adaptation  in 
developing  countries  of  Asia  and  the  Pacific  alone.8 Successful  wide-scale  deployment  of 
climate technologies will require that limited public sector funds be used to leverage far greater 
amounts of private capital. This will demand the development of financial mechanisms that can 
overcome additional risks associated with the new technologies and broader policy frameworks 
that can support climate technology transfer and diffusion. 
 
6.  Enabling public and private sector investments in climate technology will also require the 
strengthening  of  institutional  and  human  capabilities.  Financial  and  planning  policy  at  the 
national and institutional levels will need to incorporate climate technology considerations and 
develop policies to encourage technology uptake. For example, price support mechanisms, 
such  as  feed-in  tariffs  for  renewable  energy  generation,  will  need  to  be  developed  and 
assessments  of  climate  technology  needs  will  have  to  be  incorporated  into  development 
planning. Institutional mechanisms will also be required to better disseminate information on 
available climate technologies and potential financing to key stakeholders in both the public and 
private sectors and to facilitate transactions between willing buyers and sellers of technologies. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
7.  The TA, as part of a broader UNEP–ADB project, will pilot a center for the deployment of 
climate mitigation and adaptation technologies. The center will help fulfill the objectives of the 
Technology Mechanism established under the UNFCCC. The five subprojects of this TA will 
combine  with  UNEP’s  components9 to  constitute  a  cohesive  program  to  promote  climate 
technology  transfer  and  deployment  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific.  The  lessons  learned  and 
institutional capabilities generated through this program can inform and feed into nascent plans

3 
 
for operationalizing the Technology Mechanism, the details of which are still being negotiated. 
This will also enable ADB to align its existing and future operations in technology development 
and transfer as closely as possible with the considerations of the global community and allow 
ADB to respond quickly to the outcomes of UNFCCC negotiations while delivering its support to 
developing member countries (DMCs) without delay.   
 
8.  The cluster approach is proposed because (i) the subprojects are closely related, with 
common objectives and significant potential synergies, (ii) they will operate collectively as a pilot 
technology finance center to contribute to the Climate Technology Center and Network under 
climate change negotiations, and (iii) a cluster modality will mobilize financing better than an 
individual TA approach. Locating all five pilot center subprojects at ADB headquarters will also 
maximize TA coherence and coordination. The interlinked subprojects address the crosscutting 
issues  surrounding  climate  technology  transfer  identified  in  paras.  4–6.  These  are  the 
development of mechanisms and policies to facilitate technology transfer, the mobilization of 
financial resources for climate technologies, and the development of human and institutional 
capacity for technology transfer. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The overall impact of the TA will be the enhanced diffusion of technologies that promote 
low-carbon and climate-resilient development in Asia and the Pacific. The expected outcome 
will be increased investments in technologies that address climate mitigation and adaptation.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will seek on a pilot basis to establish a dedicated team of experts to help 
facilitate  investments  in  climate  technology.  This  pilot  center  will  offer  a  range  of  support 
services that will be available on demand to DMC governments, the private sector, and other 
stakeholders. The center will build upon technology initiatives conducted both within and outside 
UNFCCC  frameworks.  The  services  it  will  offer  will  facilitate  direct  investment  in  climate 
technology as well as help develop the frameworks needed to generate these investments. At 
the  country  level,  this  will  lead  to  better  policy  frameworks  to  support  climate  technology 
adoption  and,  at  the  project  level,  greater  investment  in  climate  technology  projects. 
Implementation  will  vary  between  subprojects;  therefore,  participating  DMCs  and  other 
stakeholders will be selected at the subproject level. To cover a broad portfolio of technologies 
and gain  wide  experience, the  project  and  pilot  center  activities  will  look for  balance  and 
diversity in geography and country income in deciding country beneficiaries. The criteria for 
country participation will be finalized during the initial stages of TA implementation. 
 
11.  Subproject  A: Integration  of  climate  technology  financing  needs  into  national 
development strategies, plans, and investment priorities. This subproject will incorporate 
climate  technology  considerations  into  the  ADB  country  partnership  strategy  and  country 
operation business plan processes. This will result in investment plans that are cleaner and 
more resilient environmentally. It will also promote the consideration of climate technology 
transfer  and  diffusion  in  national  development  planning  and  policymaking.  Capacity 
development within the finance, investment, and other government agencies of DMCs will be an 
important means of ensuring the strategic impact of the TA, which will include government and 
other stakeholder consultations in planning processes.

4   
12.  Subproject  B:  Promotion  of  direct  investment  in  priority  climate  technology 
projects. Projects using new climate technologies face greater technology risks and higher 
levels of investor uncertainty than incumbent technologies, as well as the resulting higher 
financing costs. This subproject will facilitate project finance for climate technology transfer by 
supporting  the  use  of  innovative  technologies  in  ADB  pipeline  investment  projects.  The 
subproject will offer specialist technical support for activities such as alternative technology 
analysis in identified priority technology areas. 
 
13.  Subproject C: Promotion of investment in climate technology products through 
venture capital funds. This subproject will help catalyze increased levels of investment in 
climate technologies by providing technical support to venture capital funds so that they can 
allocate more resources to companies with climate technology products.  As a part of ADB’s 
Asia Climate Change and Clean Energy Venture Capital Initiative, this subproject will retain a 
pool  of  experts  to  identify,  evaluate,  and  provide  advice  on  climate  technology  from  the 
technological, investment, and intellectual property rights perspectives.10 
 
14.  Subproject D: Demonstration of an assisted broker model for transfer of low-
carbon technologies to Asia and the Pacific. This subproject will address the lack of a well-
informed market for technology transfer transactions and demonstrate an assisted broker model 
for  transfer  of  low-carbon  technologies.  This  model  will  operate  as  a  marketplace  or 
matchmaking mechanism. It will work to bring together willing low-carbon technology providers 
and  recipients  and  help  facilitate  technology  transfer.  It  will  lead  the  way  toward  the 
establishment of a full-fledged business for the transfer of low-carbon technologies in Asia and 
the Pacific that can be replicated in other regions. 
 
15.  Subproject  E:  Project  management.  ADB will retain a core team to manage and 
coordinate the implementation of TA activities. The subproject will also review the scope and 
modality of the pilot center and make recomendations for its future. The core team will consist of 
management level staff, technical staff, secondees, and consultants with climate change-related 
expertise. The team will regularly communicate with the subproject teams, GEF, and other 
partners; organize meetings; and prepare reports required by ADB and partners. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The estimated total cost of the TA is $20.30 million. It breaks down as follows: (i) 
subproject A, $1.50 million; (ii) subproject B, $1.50 million; (iii) subproject C, $9 million; (iv) 
subproject D, $8 million; and (v) subproject E, $0.30 million. Of the aggregate cost, $15.05 
million will be financed by grants of (i) $2.85 million from ADB’s Climate Change Fund;11 (ii) 
$842,000 from  ADB’s Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund (TASF-other  sources); (iii)  $3.50 
million from the Asian Clean Energy Fund,12 under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership 
Facility and administered by ADB; (iv) $200,000 from VITO-Flemish Institute for Technological 
Research NV, to be administered by ADB; and (v) $7,659,091 from the GEF, to be administered 
by ADB. Funding sources for the remaining $5.25 million have yet to be identified. The cost 
estimates and financing plans are in Appendix 2.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB  will  coordinate  the  TA  through  its  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development 
Department  (RSDD).    Upon  TA  approval,  the  subproject  proposals  will  be  submitted  for 
approval to the director general of the RSDD, in accordance with ADB guidelines on cluster TA 
processing.13 ADB will be the executing agency and implementing agency for each subproject. 
The cluster TA will have a steering committee of representatives of the GEF secretariat, ADB, 
and UNEP, and other experts as needed to provide overall guidance. ADB will coordinate the 
activities  and  chair  the  steering  committee.  Separate  advisory  committees  will  also  be 
established when deemed necessary to oversee the implementation of the  subprojects. These 
advisory committees will comprise ADB staff and representatives of major donors and resource 
persons. 
 
18.  The TA will coordinate its activities with other ongoing ADB projects through existing 
institutional arrangements such as the RSDD Climate Change Program Coordination Unit, the 
Adaptation and Land-Use Working Group, and the Clean Energy Working Group. Regional 
department focal points will also be invited to contribute to the pilot center to avoid duplication of 
efforts.  The  center  will  work  closely  with  the  DMCs,  in  coordination  with  the  regional 
departments, and hold workshops to share knowledge across countries and regions. The TA is 
to be implemented from October 2011 to September 2014. 
 
19.  The TA will require national consulting inputs between 290 and 360 person-months and 
international consulting inputs between 740 and 820 person-months. Consulting inputs will be 
required from both firms and individuals.  All consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance 
with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Because 
this is a cluster TA, different methods of consultant selection will apply, depending on the size 
and nature of the contracts. The outline terms of reference for consultants for subprojects are in 
Appendix 3.  All procurement of goods and other services under the TA will be performed in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Upon 
completion of the cluster TA, all equipment procured by the consultants under the TA will be 
turned over to ADB. Disbursements under the TA will be performed in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION AND DECISION 
20.  The President recommends that the Board approve (i) ADB administering a portion of 
technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $7,659,091 to be financed on a grant basis 
by the Global Environment Facility; (ii) ADB administering a portion of technical assistance not 
exceeding the equivalent of $3,500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Asian Clean 
Energy Fund under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility; and (iii) ADB providing a 
portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $3,692,000 on a grant basis, for 
Establishing a Pilot Center to Facilitate Climate Technology Investments in Asia and the Pacific.  
If the Board approves ADB administering the technical assistance, the President, acting under 
the authority delegated by the Board, will approve ADB administering a portion of technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 to be financed on a grant basis by VITO- 
Flemish Institute for Technological Research NV for Establishing a Pilot Center to Facilitate 
Climate Technology Investments in Asia and the Pacific.

12  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The pilot center to facilitate climate technology investments in Asia and the Pacific to be 
established through cluster technical assistance (TA) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will 
consist of (i) a core team of permanent staff who will oversee the running of the constituent 
subprojects,  and  (ii)  staff  with  designated  responsibility  for  five  subprojects.  A  range  of 
consultancy inputs will be needed to supplement core staff inputs. This implies the retention of 
some international and national consultants in long-term support roles at the center. Short-term 
consultancy inputs are also likely to be required for a range of technical tasks. For some 
activities that are best packaged and managed independently of the core functions of the center, 
consultancy firms may be retained. 
 
2.  The TA will require the services of experts in climate technology policy and project 
management.  Detailed  terms  of  reference,  the  precise  extent  of  consultancy  inputs,  and 
consultant selection methods will be defined during subproject processing, in accordance with 
ADB procedures for cluster TA. Some of the key tasks consultants will undertake under each 
subproject are outlined below. 
 
A.  Subproject A: Integration of Climate Technology Financing Needs into National 
Development Strategies, Plans, and Investment Priorities 
 
1.  International  (individual;  climate  change  technology  policy  experts,  40–60 
person-months) 
 
3.  The experts will 
(i)  screen and identify suitable developing member countries (DMCs) for assistance; 
(ii)  develop and monitor subproject work plans and budgets; 
(iii)  supervise the team to ensure all deliverables are submitted on schedule; 
(iv)  conduct consultation meetings in close consultation with regional departments on 
planning and policy with national and/or subnational governments and other key 
stakeholders; 
(v)  assess the current national and/or subnational policy frameworks and review 
government  plans  and  commitments  on  promoting  climate  technologies  and 
standards and regulations for climate technology transfer and deployment; 
(vi)  provide inputs to the countries’ ADB country partnership strategies and country 
operations  business  plans  as  well  as  to  other  national  investment  planning 
activities  to  ensure  the  integration  of  best  practices,  lessons  learned,  latest 
information on climate technologies, and technology needs assessments; 
(vii)  assist in the development of plans and policies to promote climate technologies; 
(viii)  conduct training and dissemination activities with DMC government agencies; 
(ix)  support the head of the pilot technology center in general management activities, 
as required; 
(x)  assist with the development of candidate lists for consultant team positions, and 
advise the head of the pilot technology center during the selection process; 
(xi)  report to the head of the technology center on subproject management; and 
(xii)  prepare progress reports, briefing notes, and other documentation, as required.
